itemDescription: George Cross recipient in World War II

wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant Commander John Bryan Peter Duppa-Miller, GC (22 May 1903 – 15 December 1994), born John Bryan Peter Miller, was a Royal Navy officer who was awarded the George Cross for his "great gallantry and undaunted devotion to duty" in bomb disposal work during the Blitz of late 1940. He was attached to HMS Vernon and rendered safe many unexploded devices safe, including several parachute mines that fell onto the bank of the River Roding in Essex.

response: He was the son of Lieutenant-Commander Jack Duppa-Miller, GC, and Barbara Miller (née Barbara Buckmaster, daughter of the first Viscount Buckmaster, a former Lord Chancellor). Educated at Eton College, Miller graduated from Merton College, Oxford in 1956 and the University of London in 1962, and then entered colonial service in Hong Kong.
* Jack Duppa-Miller (1903–1994), British recipient of the George Cross in World War II, originally called Jack Miller
*Jack Duppa-Miller (1903–1994), Royal Navy officer who was awarded the George Cross

link_mentions.page: List of alumni of Hertford College, Oxford

response: * Jack Duppa-Miller GC, Royal Navy officer
